t: How*pn beautiful are your feet in sandals, O*ld prince’s daughter! The*ld curves of your thighs are*i like jewels, The*ld work of the hands of a skillful workman.
Your*ld navel is*i a rounded goblet; It*ld lacks no blended beverage. Your*ld waist is*i a heap of wheat Set*ld about with lilies.
Your*ld two breasts are*i like two fawns, Twins*ld of a gazelle.
Your*ld neck is*i like an ivory tower, Your*ld eyes like*i the pools in Heshbon By*ld the gate of Bath Rabbim. Your*ld nose is*i like the tower of Lebanon Which*ld looks toward Damascus.
Your*ld head crowns*i you like Mount*i Carmel, And*ld the hair of your head is*i like purple; A*ld king is*i held captive by your*i tresses.
How*ln fair and how pleasant you are, O*ld love, with your delights!
This*ld stature of yours is like a palm tree, And*ld your breasts like*i its clusters.
I*ld said, “I will go up to the palm tree, I*ld will take hold of its branches.” Let*ld now your breasts be like clusters of the vine, The*ld fragrance of your breath like apples,
And*ld the roof of your mouth like the best wine.
The*ipn wine*i goes down*i smoothly for my beloved, Moving*ld gently the lips of sleepers.
I*ld am*i my beloved’s, And*ld his desire is*i toward me.
Come,*ln my beloved, Let*ld us go forth to the field; Let*ld us lodge in the villages.
Let*ld us get up early to the vineyards; Let*ld us see if the vine has budded, Whether*ild the grape blossoms are open, And*ild the pomegranates are in bloom. There*ld I will give you my love.
The*ld mandrakes give off a fragrance, And*ld at our gates are*i pleasant fruits,*i All*ld manner, new and old, Which*ld I have laid up for you, my beloved.
